channel.title: How to create a cookie using a hyperlink? -PHP
channel.description: Im unsure how to do this, and if its even possible. I have searched google and found nothing. So I decided to ask you lot. :D

item.title: How to create a cookie using a hyperlink? -PHP
item.dc:creator: @TestDummy TestDummy
item.description:
@TestDummy wrote:

To clarify on what S!ms said, ‘=’ is one of the assignment operators. In fact, even in the first sentence on the linked page, it mentions the possible confusion between it and ‘==’, the ‘equal’ comparison operator.

The basic assignment operator is “=”. Your first inclination might be to think of this as “equal to”. Don’t. It really means that the left operand gets set to the value of the expression on the rights (that is, “gets set to”).

$a = 3;
$a += 5; // sets $a to 8, as if we had said: $a = $a + 5;

Example Name Result
$a == $b Equal TRUE if $a is equal to $b.

Read full topic

item.title: How to create a cookie using a hyperlink? -PHP
item.dc:creator: @S_ms S!ms
item.description:
@S_ms wrote:

[quote=“kloplop321, post:12, topic:162591”]if it is just ?cookie then yes. However if it is ?cookie=y then my statement will work

secondly that was copied from RXVL (not XxLegitxX)[/quote]

You don’t get me, I think. if you use a statement like if(x=y), x will always be y, since you told php to do so. Use double equal-to signs instead. if(x==y)

item.title: How to create a cookie using a hyperlink? -PHP
item.dc:creator: @kloplop321 kloplop321
item.description:
@kloplop321 wrote:

I don’t think that would work properly since you are ending the php tag.
go with
[php]<?php
$game = $_POST[‘game’];
$cookiepage = $_COOKIE[“page”];

if (isset($_POST[“submit”]))
{
setcookie(“page”, “$game”, time()+72000);
header (“Location: $cookiepage”); //don’t start with the “/”, it would be like redirecting to http://www.web.com//cokie.php
}

if (isset($_COOKIE[“page”]))
header (“Location: $cookiepage”);//don’t start with the “/”, it would be like redirecting to http://www.web.com//cokie.php
else
{
echo ’

Runescape:
Habbo:
WoW:
Guns:
';

}
?>[/php]

If you want it to work.

Read full topic

item.title: How to create a cookie using a hyperlink? -PHP
item.dc:creator: @imjohn10 imjohn10
item.description:
@imjohn10 wrote:

[code]<?php
$game = $_POST[‘game’];
$cookiepage = $_COOKIE[“page”];

if (isset($_POST[“submit”]))
{
setcookie(“page”, “$game”, time()+72000);
header (“Location: /$cookiepage”);
}

if (isset($_COOKIE[“page”]))
header (“Location: /$cookiepage”);
else
{
?>

Runescape:
Habbo:
WoW:
Guns:
<?php } ?>[/code]

should work lol

item.description:
@kloplop321 wrote:

well you could just do
[php]<?php
$createcookie = $_GET[‘cookie’];
if ($createcookie = ‘y’) {
echo ‘’;
} else {
echo “Bad Cookie. You FAIL.”
}
?>[/php]

That’s how you make it fall to pieces

item.title: How to create a cookie using a hyperlink? -PHP
item.dc:creator: @therealjdb JDB`
item.description:
@therealjdb wrote:

You could use JavaScript to set a cookie onclick but that has many drawbacks plus people need to have JavaScript enabled for that to work.

What I would probably do is, since you said it will be four different URL’s you could just have each page set a cookie then have the start page check for each cookie then redirect based on the cookie.

item.source: How to create a cookie using a hyperlink? -PHP

item.title: How to create a cookie using a hyperlink? -PHP
item.dc:creator: @RXVL RXVL
item.description:
@RXVL wrote:

You can’t. But you can have PHP read a variable from a hyperlink and create a cookie based on it.’

Example:

http://www.yoursite.com/chkcookie.php?cookie=y

<?php
$createcookie = $_GET['cookie'];
if ($createcookie = 'y') {
setcookie(name, value, expire, path, domain);
} else {
echo "Invalid Cookie. You FAIL."
}
?>

That probably has unnecessary stuff in it, because I’m still learning PHP, but it will work, I think. I wrote it off the top of my head.

Read full topic
